common

Class SmartDateParser

  • java.lang.Object
    • common.SmartDateParser

  • public final class SmartDateParser
extends java.lang.Object
    A flexible utility for converting date strings of varying formats into Date objects.

    Regional Support and Ambiguity:
    This parser is optimised for Australian/British (DD/MM/YYYY) date formats. In cases of numerical ambiguity, for example: 01/02/2026, the parser prioritises the Day-Month-Year interpretation (1st February).

    Supported Standards:

    • EXIF Standard: Handles the default yyyy:MM:dd camera format.
    • ISO-8601: Supports T delimited timestamps with optional sub-seconds.
    • International/US: Supports textual month patterns with optional commas, for example: Jan 19, 2026 or Jan 19 2026.
    Since:
    19 January 2026
    Version:
    1.0
    Author:
    Trevor Maggs

    • Method Detail

      • convertToDate

        public static java.util.Date convertToDate(java.lang.String input)
        Attempts to parse a string into a Date object by matching it against a list of known patterns.
        Parameters:
        input - the date string to parse
        Returns:
        a Date object if parsing is successful
        Throws:
        java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - if the input is null or does not match any known format

      • parseISO_8601

        private static java.util.Date parseISO_8601(java.lang.String input,
                                            java.lang.String pattern)
        Internal helper to parse ISO-8601 "T" delimited strings. This method handles optional sub-seconds and 'Z' indicators to normalise the string before parsing into the system's local time zone.
        Parameters:
        input - the raw date string, i.e. 2026-01-19T18:30:00.123Z
        pattern - the DateTimeFormatter pattern to apply, i.e. yyyy-M-d'T'HH:mm:ss
        Returns:
        a Date object if successful, otherwise null if parsing fails

      • parseDateTime

        private static java.util.Date parseDateTime(java.lang.String input,
                                            java.lang.String pattern)
        Internal helper to try various time suffixes against a base date pattern. This method iterates through TIME_FORMATS until a successful match is found. Note that it also handles the "optional comma" scenario, specifically in Indian and US formats.
        Parameters:
        input - the cleaned date string to parse
        pattern - the base date pattern without time, i.e. d/M/y
        Returns:
        a Date object representing the date/time, otherwise null if no suffixes result in a valid match
